admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
subsc: Banking,Postal services,Payments, settlements, and remittance systems

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Services
            Development Project for Azerbaijan were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the project underestimated the Technical
            Assistance (TA) needs in AzerPost and did not initially
            suggest an efficient solution in the project design. During
            the implementation, the project developed a holistic,
            multi-pillar approach to improve access to finance and
            payment services. It established a legal and governance
            framework for AzerPost to increase access to finance. Until
            early 2006, AzerPost lacked a dedicated director responsible
            for the project implementation, contributing to slow project
            launch. Due to his background, the new Deputy Director
            responsible for the project played a key role in advancing
            project implementation, raising and getting issues resolved
            with the key stakeholders throughout the project life. The
            World Bank lacked sufficient Information Technology (IT)
            procurement resources in the country office (there were two
            IT procurement experts for the entire Europe and Central
            Asia Region). This increased overall supervision costs and
            slowed down procurement process for key IT procurement
            packages significantly, respectively. Therefore, it is
            important to provide the staff and financial resources
            according to the complexity of the projects so that the lack
            thereof would not cause delays.
